text.tspan: This is an example message, featuring a long, long, long, long, long, long,
The lazy way out adds a menu item to the message menu with an attendent
popup dialog display additional details to users - this sucks requires many
actions to view message details then dismiss it again. It also means deatils
can't usefully be shown for multiple messages at once, nor remain open to
enable people to easily come back to it
This is an example message, featuring a long, long, long, long, long, long,
The embiggened message menu adds message details directly to the
message menu. Although this is nice because it reuses existing UI features,
it would make the menu somewhat unwieldly when any of the details it
displays gets too large - e.g. long sender/reply-to addresses, large numbers
of additional details, etc. It also means we can't show a contextual popup
for the Sender/Reply-To addresses, since that means you'd have a popup
on your pop-up. Yo dawg. It also suffers many of the same problems as the
This is an example message, featuring a long, long, long, long, long, long,
Using a button for expanding/hiding the details provides progressive disclosure
of the extra information and doesn't have the same issues as both the lazy
and expanded message menu. It could also be used to show the complete
recipient lists if we want to truncate them when they get large and have
It does however make the message header box larger, since it needs to fit
under the avatar icon. This could perhaps be handled by adjusting the spacing
of the sender/subject/recipients, or maybe by making the icon smaller - it is
after secondary. However if we remove the subject per Bug 714025, then
we definitely won't have enough space for it.
This is an example message, featuring a long, long, long, long, long, long,
This is an example message, featuring a long, long, long, long, long, long,
By combining expandable message detail with a message menu item to
reveal/hide it, it still takes a number of clicks to show the information,
but avoids the other issues of the lay approach. It is also explicit in what
it does, rather than relying people to mouse over the expander button,
and isn't present by default, meaning that the subject can indeed be
